revised_title: The Impact of Denervation and Excision on Tendon Growth
tldr: The study investigates the growth of tendons after the denervation or excision of their muscles in rabbits. The results show that the weight and girth of denervated muscle bellies grow to about 30% of their control counterparts, while the thickness of their tendons grows to approximately 75%. When a muscle is completely excised, its tendon grows to 85% of the control's girth. The research highlights the importance of mechanical stimuli and muscle-tendon junction structure in tendon growth.
scientific_discipline: Biology and Life Sciences > Anatomy and Physiology
